div.head: Typology (Local)
div.p: East (Mashreq) > Arabia > Northern group > Northern Najd

div.head: General
div.p: The Šammar are one of the largest Bedouin tribal confederations of Arabia. Traditionally, their lifestyle used to be that of nomadic camel rearers. Most are sedentarized nowadays. They are located mainly in Saudi-Arabia, Syria and Iraq. According to their oral history, three of their tribes descend from the Qaḥṭānite Ṭayyiˀ in Yemen (al-Aslam, al-Xrīṣih and Sinǧārih, the latter two often grouped together as Zūbiʿ), who formed the Šammar section of Ṭayyiˀ. The fourth tribe, ˁAbdih, also descendants of Qaḥṭān, came to present-day Saudi Arabia at a later stage and joined the confederation.

While many settled in Jebel Šammar in northern Arabia, and the oasis city of Ḥā’il, some migrated north. Of those northern or Mesopotamian Šammar, some became Shiites and there is also a small Christian minority. Ḥā’il was an important station for the pilgrims from Iran and Iraq and the Šammar guaranteed their security and levied fees from the caravans. Thus, they played a powerful role and the Emirate of the Āl Rašīd was a Šammarī emirate.

The traditional rivals of the Šammar are the ˁAnaza, and all factions except the al-Aslam were also in opposition to the Āl Suˁūd and their Wahhabite allies. After the foundation of Saudi Arabia in 1923, this eventually impeded their employment in lucrative sectors such as the National Guard forces. The Land Redistribution Act caused the loss of their tribal dīra. Many joined their tribesmen in Iraq, where they still enjoy a prominent position in society.

div.head: Research history
div.p: Ingham, who has conducted much research on the Šammar, states that their dialect is largely homogenous despite their dispersal over a vast area. Cantineau in two consecutive articles (1936 and 1937) explores Bedouin dialects on the Arabian peninsula, preceded by Montagne 1935 on the Šammar of the Ǧazīra in Iraq.
Abboud 1964 is a dissertation on the dialect spoken in Ḥā’il, followed by three articles: Abboud 1975 on verb suffixation, Abboud 1978 on the imperfect prefix and Abboud 1979 on the verb in general.

Sowayan, who has worked on oral Bedouin poetry and history, published annotated texts in two articles (Sowayan 1982a and 1982b) and a monograph (Sowayan 1992), the latter also offering comments on the grammar of the Šammar dialect, especially syntax.
Behnstedt 1997 offers data on the Šammar in Syria, and also provides a good collection of texts.

Ingham, whose work on Bedouin dialects and the dialects of the Arabian peninsula is ample, has treated the Šilgān branch of the Šammar in Ingham 1982. Virtually all of his works on Najdi Arabic include examples from the Šammari dialect, such as Ingham 1994 and Ingham 2006, and most recently Ingham 2010. Ingham also links the fringe dialect of the Euphrates Bedouins to the Šammar dialect group (Ingham 2009).
Recently, three articles discussed the peculiar feminine ending in the Šammari dialect: Van Putten 2017, Procházka 2021 and Alshammari 2021.

div.head: Dictionaries
div.p: Sowayan 1992 includes a 60 page glossary of typical Šammari vocabulary.
